newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: LITHUANIA-EU TEXTILE EXPORT CEILINGS INCREASED.
newsitem.headline: LITHUANIA-EU TEXTILE EXPORT CEILINGS INCREASED.

text.p: A joint EU-Lithuania commmittee decided to raise tariff ceilings for Lithuanian textiles exported to the European Union (EU) and liberalise the domestic market, a foreign ministry official said on Tuesday.
"The ceilings will be raised and Lithuania is eliminating a number of import tariffs for EU textiles," Algimantas Rimkunas, deputy foreign minister of Lithuania, told reporters.
He did not give the details of the agreement, finalised at Tuesday a meeting of a joint Lithuania-EU committee which works on a free trade agreement.
The EU accounted for 33.4 percent of Lithuania's exports last year and 40.5 percent of its imports.
Lithuania's exports to the EU amounted to 4.384 billion litas and imports from the EU were 7.133 billion litas.
According to Rimkunas, textiles make up 29 percent of Lithuania's exports to the EU.
"For some products, ceilings were raised very considerably, from two million items to seven million items per year," Rimkunas said.
Rimkunas said the Lithuanian goods that would enjoy higher ceilings included items like T-shirts and sweaters.
"The products that Lithuania exports are quite considerable," Rimkunas said.
